But economist Keith Reed has some ideas on how to get off on the good foot this year.
He's a reporter for the Cincinnati Enquirer and he has just launched BET's personal finance blog, ""Dollar Out of 15 Cents."" Hey, Keith.
What's up, Farai?
Well, what's up is reality check, you know?
It's time to take a look at what's left in the wallet.
How do you start off on the right foot in terms of savings, for example?
I think one of the things that people should have done before you even start to talk about getting on - off on the right foot this year in terms of savings was look at what you did last year.

If you've got those receipts that are still left or the bills that are coming due, really look at what you spent last year, really look at how much of a consumer you were during the holiday season, and figure out what you can do to cut back your spending in some areas that you didn't necessarily need to spend.
That would be one of the first things.
I mean, one of the biggest things that I think a lot of people don't do anymore or aren't as disciplined about as they should be is budgeting.
You really have to sit down, look at what you're bringing in every month or every other week or however often it is that you get paid and figure out what you're spending.

Take a pen and a piece of paper with you outside when you, you know, when you go to work or when you're shopping on the weekends and write down everything that you spent, all the little things that you don't keep track of.

Figure out where that money is going and start to work back with from there to see what you can cut out from your budget, so that you can be more disciplined and not end up owing in the New Year as much as you may have owed in the prior year.
That will be the number one place I would start for most folks.
What about actual savings plans?
They're - you can get such low interest rates on money that you just keep in a savings account that's linked to your checking account.
What other options do you have if you don't want to have your money tied up for a long time, but you do want to get some money in terms of interest?
One of the great things you can do is obviously look into an online savings account.

Two to the most popular accounts that are out there are ING Direct's Orange Account and HSBC Direct is an online subsidiary of HSBC bank, where you can go online, you can have a direct deposit or an automatic deposit set up to come out of your either your paycheck or your checking account, link that to your online account.

Those banks, because they don't have physical branches, are - they don't have the overheads, so they pass those savings on an overhead from running a branch onto you in a form of higher interest rates.
Right now, I think both of those banks have given in the 4 maybe even 5 percent range, and sometimes for new accounts, you can get APYs that are a little bit higher than even for 4 or 5 percent.
Sometimes, you'll find promotions that go as high as - close to 6 percent on the money that you put into some of those accounts.
And it's a very good way to save your money.
The other thing that's great about those things is that when you put the money in, because it doesn't come with an ATM card, it's a little bit more difficult to get access to the money.

So for example if you have an ING account, if you put money into that account, it takes at least three days for the money to come back to you if you need to transfer it into a checking account that you have access to.
So in those three days, you've got a little bit of time to think.
It's not money that you can just go get and make an impulse purchase with.
So those are two really, really good vehicles for putting some money away.
The other thing that you want to start to do is look at where you are in your 401(k).
You can put as much as 25 percent of your income, in some instances, into a 401(k).
You're going to look at your company's match or do you have enough money in that 401(k) to take advantage of the match that you're making.
Did you make enough of a contribution to your IRA - all of those things.
And again, start with looking at what you've actually budgeted.
Some of the money that you take out of your budget from discretionary spending, you should immediately start to put toward savings.
All right.

And suppose that you're someone who says, all right, well, I'm going to get a jump.
It's not going to be April 12, me, sitting around covered in papers and crying and, you know, calling to a higher power to get me out of this fix.
What can you do now to keep you from that situation?

Start right now from getting organized, really, again sit down, take a look at some of the spending that you did last year, where are some of the areas that some of the things that you spent may be taxed right off.
Do you have all of the receipts that you use for things, for your home?
For example, if you're a homeowner, do you - did you keep the receipts for all of the maintenance that you did on your home?
Look at some of the things that you may be able to write off, the expenses that you paid in for work.
Did you drive a certain number of miles for work that you didn't get reimbursed for?
Did you spend money on equipment or things that you needed for your job that the job didn't spent you for - didn't reimburse you for.
You may be able to write some of those - that stuff off on your taxes.
Do you maintain a home office?
Some of that space you might be able to write off on your taxes if you are a renter, but you use one room dedicated in your home as an office.
Keep the receipts, keep track of all of the things that you're spending and start to look at what some of the tax rules are.
One very important thing, I wrote about this last year.
There is a movement that we don't hear very much about, but there's a movement around the country to get people to take advantage of the earned income tax credit.
It's a tax credit that applies to a very narrow section of taxpayers in the United States.
It tends to be people who have - who are working parents, people who are working but don't make a ton of money and their parents.

You need to check whether or not you qualify for the earned income tax credit and make sure that if you do that you take advantage of it both at the federal and many states have a matching tax credit to go along with that federal tax credit.

I drive a UConn van into the middle of campus, and I unload all of the cannabis plants into the largest lecture hall (laughter).

Today, she'll transport these hemp plants from the greenhouse.
There's a lot of ooh-ing and ah-ing generally, especially when you're, like, carrying them on carts.
Hemp and marijuana are both types of cannabis, but chemically, they're different.
Hemp has cannabidiol, or CBD, but not enough THC to produce the high induced by marijuana.
Hemp is used in everything from beauty products to clothing, and UConn's teaching a whole class on growing just this one kind of plant.
All right.
Welcome, everyone.
Madison Blake is one of around 300 students in the class.

Instructor Matthew DeBacco says the goal is to present a scientifically backed way to grow and to dispel myths that for years may have passed between illicit growers.

Debacco wants the research-backed processes students get in this class to be directly infused into the cannabis industry.
He says the lessons students learn on hemp are directly transferable to marijuana, and markets for hemp and marijuana are growing.

Berkowitz says years of that culture combined with tight federal research regulations means there's been little study of cannabis.
There's lack of peer review.
There's lack of scholarship.
There's lack of sharing of information.
Berkowitz and his students have been running controlled experiments on hemp at UConn for around three years.
And as more academics get into the field, he's hopeful courses like this will make cannabis research blossom.
